answers.answer: Does your grandmother have hep C? It's not clear why you concerned.Tossing used needles and syringes in the trash is not the proper way to dispose of them.  Get a sharps container from the pharmacy.

You probably would have felt it, especially since you were forcefully bending the needle. However, insulin needles are very small so it is possible to get stuck and not feel it.Even if you were stuck and did not feel it, that does not mean you have contracted a bloodborne disease. To beging with, your grandmother would have to have a bloodborne disease in order to give one to you. If she has none, you cannot get one (from her).If you are still concerned, talk with your doctor and get tested for Hepatitis and HIV.In the future, it would be advisable to NOT recap needles and NOT throw them in the ordinary garbage can. There are "sharps" containers that are specifically manufactured for the disposal of needles and syringesand the reason they exist is to prevent people from accidentally sticking themselves (either while recapping the needle or while handing the "trash."Ask your pharamcy where to get a sharps container.Here are a couple of links to information on sharps disposal:http://www.epa.gov/osw/nonhaz/industrial/medical/disposal.htmhttp://bd.com/us/diabetes/page.aspx?cat=7002&id=7414http://www.sharpsdisposal.com/
I don't know if she has it or not.  But if she does would you usually always feels a needle in your finger?
Just ask her...then it matter if you got stuck or not.

1. Only 2% of the population has hepatitis C.2. You didn't even feel a needle stick3. You had no bleeding4. Since you are injecting your grandmother you should know that the Insulin is injected into the subcutaneous fat layer below the skin above the blood vessels. It is not injected into her veins.You are being paranoid.If you are still worried go get tested.Hector

I have type 1 diabetes and have stuck myself in the finger MANY times.YES, you do feel it.As mentioned above, if you are assisting another person with insulin injections you know that it is not injected into the bloodstream.  It is injected into fat.

question: I hope I am just being overly worried.  I am taking care of my grandmother and give her insulin. A few nights ago the cap fell and we could not find it so I took the end of the needle wrapped it in napkins, bent the needle back against the side of the garbage can and tapped it (to avoid a garbage man getting stuck).   Now I did not feel anything while doing this nor did I have any spots that seemed to be bleeding.  But afterwards I started to question with the needle being hidden in the napkins and taped if I was careful enough to make sure I did not get stuck.  So my question is if I would have been stuck would I have felt it?  I am 30yo and have no health problems so I have normal sensitivity in my fingers.  Thanks
title: Needle stick..but not feel it?
